messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 44 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: On the Fine-Grained Hardness of Inverting Generative Models

Paper Abstract: Abstract The objective of generative model inversion is to identify a size-nùëõn latent vector that produces a generative model output that closely matches a given target. This operation is a core computational primitive in numerous modern applications involving computer vision and NLP. However, the problem is known to be computationally challenging and NP-hard in the worst case. This paper aims to provide a fine-grained view of the landscape of computational hardness for this problem. We establish several new hardness lower bounds for both exact and approximate model inversion. In exact inversion, the goal is to determine whether a target is contained within the range of a given generative model. Under the strong exponential time hypothesis (SETH), we demonstrate that the computational complexity of exact inversion is lower bounded by Œ©‚Äã(2n)Œ©superscript2ùëõ\Omega(2^{n}) via a reduction from kùëòk-SAT; this is a strengthening of known results. For the more practically relevant problem of approximate inversion, the goal is to determine whether a point in the model range is close to a given target with respect to the ‚Ñìpsubscript‚Ñìùëù\ell_{p}-norm. When pùëùp is a positive odd integer, under SETH, we provide an Œ©‚Äã(2n)Œ©superscript2ùëõ\Omega(2^{n}) complexity lower bound via a reduction from the closest vectors problem (CVP). Finally, when pùëùp is even, under the exponential time hypothesis (ETH), we provide a lower bound of 2Œ©‚Äã(n)superscript2Œ©ùëõ2^{\Omega(n)} via a reduction from Half-Clique and Vertex-Cover.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 44 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 44"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Generative adversarial nets",
        "High-resolution image synthesis with latent diffusion models",
        "Hierarchical text-conditional image generation with CLIP latents",
        "GAN inversion: A survey",
        "Global guarantees for enforcing deep generative priors by empirical risk",
        "A provably convergent scheme for compressive sensing under random generative priors",
        "Fast and provable admm for learning with generative priors",
        "Provable compressed sensing with generative priors via langevin dynamics",
        "Compressed sensing using generative models",
        "Inverting deep generative models, one layer at a time",
        "Tight hardness results for lcs and other sequence similarity measures",
        "Seth vs approximation",
        "Fine-grained complexity theory: Conditional lower bounds for computational geometry",
        "Why we couldn‚Äôt prove seth hardness of the closest vector problem for even norms, and of the subset sum problem!",
        "The fine-grained hardness of sparse linear regression",
        "Atomic decomposition by basis pursuit",
        "Cosamp: Iterative signal recovery from incomplete and inaccurate samples",
        "Model-based compressive sensing",
        "One network to solve them all‚Äîsolving linear inverse problems using deep projection models",
        "Learning to invert: Signal recovery via deep convolutional networks",
        "Deep image prior",
        "Algorithmic guarantees for inverse imaging with untrained network priors",
        "Deep compressed sensing",
        "Information-theoretic lower bounds for compressive sensing with generative models",
        "Solving linear inverse problems using gan priors: An algorithm with provable guarantees",
        "Compressed sensing with invertible generative models and dependent noise",
        "Invertible generative models for inverse problems: mitigating representation error and dataset bias",
        "Density estimation using real NVP",
        "Conditional sampling from invertible generative models with applications to inverse problems",
        "On the complexity of k-sat",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "Beyond p vs. np: quadratic-time hardness for big data problems",
        "Lower bounds based on the exponential time hypothesis",
        "Edit distance cannot be computed in strongly subquadratic time (unless seth is false)",
        "Why walking the dog takes time: Frechet distance has no strongly subquadratic algorithms unless seth fails",
        "Quadratic conditional lower bounds for string problems and dynamic time warping",
        "If the current clique algorithms are optimal, so is valiant‚Äôs parser",
        "Subquadratic high-dimensional hierarchical clustering",
        "On the fine-grained complexity of empirical risk minimization: Kernel methods and neural networks",
        "Optimal-degree polynomial approximations for exponentials and gaussian kernel density estimation",
        "Hardness of approximate nearest neighbor search",
        "On the computational complexity of self-attention",
        "On the quantitative hardness of cvp",
        "Fine-grained hardness of cvp (p)‚Äîeverything that we can prove (and nothing else)"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 44 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in On the Fine-Grained Hardness of Inverting Generative Models, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
